Posts.Content: May 11, 2012 09:54PM GrandmaV wrote: MY biopsy was not painful.  The only stick I felt was the local anesthetic and then I felt nothing.  They did a sonogram guided biopsy and set the monitor so I could see my lump and the needle go into it (I had asked to watch the monitor, you don't have to watch if you don't want to).  The breast surgeon that did mine explained everything as they went along.  They took 4 samples from different parts of the lump.  It did ache some for a couple of days and looked bruised, but I was able to take Tylenol and that took care of the pain.   I'm hoping with you for a B9 result.

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2012 12:32PM - edited Sep 10, 2012 12:33PM by GrandmaV Tracylee,  The waiting is awful.  I'm hoping you do hear something Wednesday.  mrm68, I'm not sure what conflicting info you've gotten.  If you're asking what the biopsy is like, I can only tell you about my experience.  With the core needle biopsy, they used ultrasound to guide them to the core of the mass.  They give you a shot to deaden the area and in my case the doctor had the monitor where I could see it too and explained everything we were seeing.  They took 4 samples from mine, and there was no pain during the biopsy.  I found it very interesting to watch the monitor and see the needle go into the mass.  It seemed like it was happening to some one else.  I could feel some pressure, but that's all.  He showed me the lymph nodes that were close to the lump and said they looked normal (he was right).  He rushed the pathology report through and I got a call from him the next evening with the news.  We didn't get the complete path report until the next week.  After the biopsy I had some bruising, but it was not too painful.   The bruising took a couple of weeks to go away.  I was pleasantly surprised how good it went, so all that worrying I did about it was for nothing, except, of course, I did get the news it was cancer, but I was pretty sure it was anyway.  I know others have said they had pain during the biopsy, but that was not my experience.  If you feel pain, ask to have it deadened more.  I hope it goes well for you and you get B9 results.
Posts.Title: Quick question Tracyleepeach69 mrm68

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2012 11:05AM - edited Jun 20, 2012 11:07AM by GrandmaV Suzanne, It sounds like you're doing everything right to find out about this pain you're having.   Ultrasound should reveal any abnormality.  I don't know anything about cyclical pain.  When I was still having periods my breasts would get very sore about a week or two before my period.  I never had it in just one place, but that doesn't mean it doesn't happen.  Other women may have had that experience.   The one little pea sized lump, you could request a biopsy on it, might put your mind at ease.  It kind of sounds like an injury to a nerve ending.  I say that because after my lumpectomy, I've had no feeling in about half of my breast, but lately the nerve endings are waking up and I have a pain now and again.  Since you have a strong family history, maybe you could get tested for the Brca gene mutation to see if you are at greater risk for breast cancer.  Here's a link that explains that better than I could:  http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/factsheet/Risk/BRCA I hope you can find out soon what this is, because waiting in fear is terrible. Hugs

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2012 10:15PM - edited Jul 12, 2012 10:19PM by GrandmaV Aruba and mlo69, I'm sorry to hear about your diagnosis.  But at least you know what you are facing.  It sounds like you both have early stage breast cancer and there are so many treatment options today.  It would be a good idea to take someone with you to take notes and be an extra pair of ears.  I record all my doctor's appointments.  Ask for copies of everything, pathology reports, results of tests, blood work, etc.  I encourage you to start a journal or blog, to keep track of the day to day things, especially during treatment, whether that be surgery, chemo, radiation, hormon blocker, etc.  You will want to know what are your chances of recurrence are without each treatment and with each treatment, as well as side effects and risks, so you can make informed decisions of whether the benefit outweighs the risks.  Ask what your prognosis is.  You will need to know if you need to change your diet or supplements during treatment.  Try to research each step of your treatment one at a time. If you try to research all of them at the same time you'll get overwhelmed. Also ask questions here on BCO. If I think of anything else I'll post again. Hope it all goes smoothly for you. lots of hugs  edited to add:  The link the moderators gave you is very thorough to ask your surgeon

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2012 04:45PM GrandmaV wrote: Nikki, I agree with Omaz and Joanne.   Before my biopsy I asked my breast surgeon if she could just remove the lump instead of a biopsy and she said that is no longer how they do it.  When I asked why, she explained that they used to do it that way and take a bunch of lymph nodes too, but now they know that it's not always necessary to take as many lymph nodes.  They like to do the biopsy first and then can plan the surgery.  They can locate the sentinel lymph node and only take it and sometimes a few others.  If you have surgery without the planning it can drastically reduce their ability to find the sentinel lymph node.  Please get a second opinion from a breast surgeon who is up on all the new ways of doing things.  From what I've read about lymphedema, you definitely want to avoid getting that if you can. http://newsatjama.jama.com/2011/07/26/author-insights-extensive-lymph-node-surgery-no-longer-needed-for-most-women-with-breast-cancer/

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2012 06:42PM - edited Jun 18, 2012 06:48PM by GrandmaV LPR, I have no insight to give you.  I'm just so sorry your mom has to deal with this at her age.  I have a friend who is in her 80's and was diagnosed about 9 months before I was.  She had a mastectomy.  I don't know much about her cancer, except that it was about the size of walnut (her description) and no node involvement.  She refused chemo, because she felt the risks too great with her other health problems.  My mother didn't have bc but did have chronic lymphatic leukemia in her 70's and refused chemo for the same reasons, although they did have a targeted therapy called rituxen that she did take and got her CLL into remission.  It will really depend on what your mom is willing to do.   I do think its important to get the mass out.  This web site from the cancer society might help her decide, after she knows what kind of cancer and stage: http://www.cancer.org/Cancer/BreastCancer/DetailedGuide/breast-cancer-treating-by-stage edited to add: http://www.moffitt.org/CCJRoot/v14n1/pdf/44.pdf

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2011 06:46AM GrandmaV wrote: Hi ladies,  My BS had me come to her office to check me out.  I still have allergies or cold but seem better.   She listened to my lungs and they were clear, and had no fever.  She and my Onc had originally both recommended a lumpectomy with radiation, and I had thought I wanted a BMX but told her I wasn't sure, I was going to do research on the two.  So she reserved the OR for the longer surgery and said I could let her know on the day of surgery and she would plan on the BMX but keep my other options open too.  And since it is a longer surgery  she wanted to wait a few days and see if the cold cleared up.  She thought it would be Thursday, or Friday, if she could reserve the OR that day, but couldn't guarantee that.  I reminded her I have seasonal asthma and said I'm  afraid the allergies/cold will trigger it and if that happens, I could start coughing and it could last weeks.  So far it hasn't happened, but is a real possibility.  So this would actually be the best time to do it.  Then I told her I had waffled back and forth between my options and was really starting to lean toward lumpectomy because of the risk factors I have for lymphedema.  I'm also scared of the radiation side effects so couldn't decide which way to go, My husband and I had talked it over and I was so distraught about it, that he didn't know what to do.    Then I got this allergy/cold thing and it about sent me over the edge to think my surgery would be postponed, and I thought if it was postponed I would go completely out of my mind.  I said I think I'm more afraid of lymphedema than I am of radiation and was probably going to go with the lumpectomy.  So if I did and that's a much shorter time under anesthesia, could I go ahead and have the lumpectomy tomorrow.  She was very sympathetic and did another sonogram on my cancer breast to see if that is still an option.  And said it was.  So she said she was concerned though that I was making that decision because I might start coughing and wheezing and was just acting out of fear.  I told her more about my research and that I was leaning toward the lumpectomy before I got the cold, but I agreed that the cold is the thing that tipped the scales to go with the lumpectomy instead, but that when I think of the BMX or that it is going to be postponed, I'm just overwhelmed.  She really took the time to make sure that was really what I wanted to do and agreed to the lumpectomy tomorrow,SNB and the port a cath.  That will shorten the time I'm under anesthesia by about half.  But it could still be postponed tomorrow morning if I have a fever and it depends on what the anesthesiologist recommends, I won't meet him/her until I get to the hospital.  But I feel so relieved that I'm having the lumpectomy.  I know going that route doesn't guarantee I won't get lymphedema but it cuts the chances of that down by a lot.  I wish this rotten allergy/cold would just stop already.  But thats how it stands tonight.  I'll go to the hospital and find out if it's still a go.  I'm sorry this is such a long post, but it's very complicated and I know you all understand how I feel.  Thanks for all the well wishes and encouragement, it helps a lot.

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2012 10:56PM GrandmaV wrote: lettiegonz, It is overwhelming when you're first diagnosed.  You can ask for the results of all your tests.  Ask for a copy of your pathology report from your biopsy.  It will tell you a lot about your cancer.  I had a lumpectomy last October and didn't have a drain.  In fact I didn't have much pain with it or the sentinal node dissection.  I also had a port placed at the time of my surgery.  I was pretty much healed up after the first couple of weeks.  Still had some bruising but none of it was very bad.  I was just reading another thread about someone else who just had a lumpectomy.  It has a lot of information.  Here's the link for that:  http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/91/topic/786356?page=2#idx_31 There is also a thread with a shopping and to do list before surgery: http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/91/topic/699896?page=15#idx_421 Did they explain to you about the sentinal node dissection?  They insert a dye into your nipple before surgery so they know the main lymph node to take out.  I was very scared about this, but was pleasantly surprised that it didn't hurt.  They numb the area first.  This is all very scarey.  Do you have a friend or someone you can take with you?  I took either my daughter or husband with me to all appointments and I bought a little voice recorder to record all my doctor's appointments.  We're here for you, you're not alone. Best wishes and hugs.

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2012 05:04PM GrandmaV wrote: Anniet,I would be very concerned about the 30% chance of recurrence, when you consider that there was only a 20% chance that our lumps were cancer in the first place.  Does your doctor think the radiation you received for Hodgkins was the cause?  There is a thread on this site where ladies who have experienced this hang out.  Here's the link: http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/47/topic/764830?page=2#post_2553280 If you post your question there they may be able to help.

Posts.Title: Any October 2011 Surgeries out there want to wait together? gamergirl GrandmaV

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2011 08:00PM GrandmaV wrote:   I will be on herceptin for a year after chemo.  I will also have rads after chemo. and be on a hormone blocker for 5 years.  I got my pathology report today and it was actually better than I thought it would be.  After the sonogram guided biopsy they estimated my tumor at 2.6cm but after surgery it measured 1.7cm.  Also after the biopsy I could feel my nodes swell.  The surgeon even thought they looked suspicious after my sonogram just before surgery.  But they came out clear.  I meet with my onc next Wednesday and since I had a port put in at surgery will start chemo soon and find out the staging.    I hope everyone who has had surgery will have a speedy recovery and everyone still facing surgery you are in my thoughts and hope everything goes well.

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2011 04:13PM GrandmaV wrote: Hi rachelvk, You've probably already thought of this.  Could your BF move in with you at your current apartment and help pay the extra expense until you can get past and recover from treatment? Or, and I know this would be hard for me to do, Just turn it over to the family and friends and let them pack you up and move you.  Maybe put some stuff in storage (family and friends may have some space) until you can sort through it.  It is a difficult situation and I hope all the best for you. Hugs
Posts.Title: Any October 2011 Surgeries out there want to wait together? gamergirl GrandmaV

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2011 05:24AM GrandmaV wrote: Hi everyone, I was diagnosed Sept. 1.  I just found out my surgery is scheduled for Oct. 11.  So, could I be added to the list, too?  I've been reading posts in the forums for a while and was a little shy about joining in.  I think I've been in shock for the last two weeks.  I'm having a BMX, but I'm not having reconstruction.  They're also going to put in a port-a-cath during the surgery and I think that's the part that scares me the most.  I was hoping my surgery would be sooner.  This waiting is driving me insane.  Every little pain or cough and I think, is this cancer spreading?  It helps to see that I'm not alone in this. Thanks
Posts.Title: Any October 2011 Surgeries out there want to wait together? gamergirl GrandmaV

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2011 04:14PM GrandmaV wrote: Maria_Malta, thank you for welcoming me.  I can relate to your decision for BMX without reconstruction.  I'm 57 so we're about the same age.  The 3 reasons you gave are exactly how I feel.  I've been getting all kinds of well meaning advice from family and friends, but they just can't know what it's like to face this kind of decision.  Just when I'm sure it's what I want, someone will try to talk me out of it.  So glad to know someone else who's going through this, feels as I do.  I hope all goes well with your ultra-sound Monday, so you can move on to your next step. Thank you so much for your post. GrandmaV

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2019 06:15PM - edited Mar 5, 2019 06:18PM by GrandmaV Hi everyone, I'm struggling. 7 years on Ai's has taken a toll. I had 2nd primary in opposite breast in 2017 and finally had bmx. Haven't been the same since. But glad to be alive. Thought about stopping Ai at 7 years because of study that said 10 no better than 7. But breast cancer index said 5 extra years would cut risk. Not sure what to do. Glad to know others are doing well.
Posts.Title: Any October 2011 Surgeries out there want to wait together? gamergirl GrandmaV

Posts.Content: May 12, 2012 08:43PM GrandmaV wrote: Only a male surgeon would tell you to get a psychological evaluation.  A Woman would understand your thinking.  It seems to me that you are doing all the right things in trying to be as well informed as you can.  Keep in mind that you have time.  It is hard to seperate our emotions at times from what is the educated thing to do.  But also you (not the surgeon) should have the choice in your treatment.   Lots of hugs.

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2012 11:47PM GrandmaV wrote: For peace of mind, maybe you could have one of your other doctors move it up to November.   I know I wouldn't be able to wait.  It probably would be ok to have it in January, but it's just not worth the added worry to wait.  Your mental and emotional state is just as important to fight recurrence as the treatments you've already been through.
Posts.Title: Mamogram after radiation? Rose12 Megadotz

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2012 06:08AM GrandmaV wrote: I'm not sure how to advise you.  If this has been going on only a few days you could wait and watch to see if they go away.  If you just got rid of the bugs last week, is it possible some of them survived?  if you're not comfortable waiting,  you could make an appointment with your regular doctor to get it checked out. I know it's hard not to be anxious about it, but Breast cancer is very rare in someone so young.   There are many things it could be, that are not cancer.  Lots of hugs
Posts.Title: Red dots on my breast turned purple.. Martinez26 CuterWCurves

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2011 09:14PM GrandmaV wrote: I had my surgery.  I had a lumpectomy, port a cath and SNB.  I went home the same day.  Was pretty much asleep all day yesterday, until evening.  I started having a slight fever Wednesday evening.  My BS said it's not unusual to have a slight fever after surgery, but she also said it may be due to what I came down with over the weekend and not related to the surgery.   They're going to start an antibiotic just to be on the safe side and hopefully avoid infection in the surgical incisions.  None of the incisions look red.  I'm just glad I got my surgery before the fever started.  The highest it got was 100.7 degrees.  The pain pills I'm taking make me sleepy, and am afraid to let them wear off.  The most painful area is my neck.  Where they made an incision to place the port.  But it's tolerable with the pain meds take care of it.  I will write more when I can keep my eyes open.  Thank you for all your encouragement.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2011 05:18AM GrandmaV wrote: Susanella, Welcome to our group.  It's been a very emotional week for all of us, because some of the surgeries didn't turn out as expected.  I know you're terrified, I am too.  Especially the closer it gets to surgery day.  I'm not having reconstruction, so I can't help you there.  I just don't want any more surgery then I have to have.  I'm new at this too, so don't know too much.  But you have come to a group of amazing women, who have a lot of love and support to give to each other.  We have a long road ahead of us but we have to keep moving forward and be determined to beat this.  There are set backs and disappointments, but there is always hope.  You're doing the right thing, in that you're trying to learn all you can to make good decisions.  Hang in there.

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2012 12:20PM GrandmaV wrote: yes, fibrocystic lumps can be in your armpit, as well as hormonal changes, cysts, infection and a virus your body is fighting can cause a lymph node to swell.  A biopsy is a good idea to know for sure what it is and odds are it is B9.  Hope all goes well for you. Hugs

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2012 06:49PM GrandmaV wrote: My breast surgeon told me if it was the same on both sides that it was nothing to worry about.  I thought the nodes just above my collar bone seemed swollen, but it's the same on both sides, so she said it was probably fatty deposits or fluid.  I liked that answer so I'm going with it.
